reviewText: Robin Shou's Hong Kong film career remains consistently overshadowed by his Hollywood accomplishments and obscure at best, and when considering lackluster offerings like "Interpol Connection", I can't say I'm too eager to excavate the rest of it. What we have here is a truly missed opportunity of Robin abandoning his usual henchman status in favor of a numbingly dull lead role alongside a similarly underutilized Yukari Oshima in a movie so deprived of action that it hardly deserves to be called a Hong Kong picture. The story: following the death of his partner at the hands of an international crime lord (director Philip Ko, Angel on Fire), Hong Kong policeman Co Chi Pang (Shou, Mortal Kombat) follows the criminal to the Philippines, where he will need to team with a lethal Japanese Interpol agent (Oshima, Riki-Oh) to capture the crook. This movie is so obscure that even websites like HKCinemagic can't provide its full cast list, so I can't even identify the inept and annoying Filipino policeman Shou is also teamed up with. This guy supplies the token comedy portions of the film, but unless you consider a grown man wetting his pants and wearing a bra to be humorous, you'll be as displeased with him as I was. Sadly, this buffoon's antics are the most interesting things you'll witness in the movie's lifeless first 50 minutes: save for a few tired shootouts, there's hardly a trace of action scenes for almost the entire first hour, during which Robin Shou's character investigates stuff and visits a strip joint. Riveting, no? Yukari Oshima doesn't show up until that 50 minute mark, and luckily, she brings the fights with her. We get four hand-to-hand scenes in the last half-hour, which Oshima is clearly the star of. Action director Dion Lam (The Storm Riders) had yet to come into his niche as one of the best in the business, but he gives her a couple of good brawls: one with a high-kicking henchman that turns into a stickfight and one with Philip Ko during which she spider-climbs a doorframe to pummel him. Shou, on the other hand, has definitely seen better days: though the movie's intro showcases his excellent physique, his single one-on-one fight with another unnamed henchman (who may be Simon Kim from Xtreme Fighter) features a drastic amount of editing for a Hong Kong movie and a lot of his jumping around in general looks like it was done by a stunt double. Positively not his best work. On the whole, I give the fight content an average but passing grade, and therein it saves this movie from a one-star rating. It's painful for me to write such a negative review for a film starring a man I admire so much, but it just doesn't have enough redeeming qualities to balance out its negative aspects. Don't waste your money, folks. If you really want to see Shou in a Hong Kong movie, check out Death Cage - at least that one has enough fight scenes.
